messageBody:
How do you do TDD with a separate, independent tester?
That goes against what TDD is, unless the tester is
pair programming with the developer.

I do sometimes worry though that my testcode doesn't
test the boundary cases too well since it is not my
dedicated job to make the code break. But, with TDD
my code is 90-100% tested whereas otherwise it would
be 10% (if that). That is such a marked improvement
that I think it is well worth it, even without
independent testing.

---- Lauren Bish wrote: -----
I should have added that I find it useful to have both
TDD and Unit
testing
that is done by a dedicated unit tester. Not many
developers have the
proper
attitude for testing; testing takes a somewhat
destructive attitude,
while
writing code is a creative process. Also, many
developers don't have
the
aptitude or expertise for testing. This is not a slam
on developers,
just a
recognition that testing and developing (both of which
I have done) are
two
different areas of expertise.
